Sequencing Simulation

Source: vignettes/sequencing.Rmd
sequencing.Rmd

Once a phylogenetic forest has been computed (see vignette("mutations")) for the details), rRACES/RACES can simulate the sequencing of the samples in the forest and return the observed data.

Sequencing Simulation

Let us consider the phylogenetic forest produced in vignette("mutations").

library(rRACES)

phylo_forest <- load_phylogenetic_forest("phylo_forest.sff")

phylo_forest
#> PhylogeneticForest
#>   # of trees: 1
#>   # of nodes: 4773
#>   # of leaves: 953
#>   samples: {"S_1_1", "S_1_2", "S_2_1", "S_2_2"}
#> 
#>   # of emerged SNVs: 70051
#>   # of emerged CNAs: 2

The loaded phylogenetic forest models the cell evolution of 4 different samples: S_1_1, S_1_2, S_2_1, and S_2_2.

We can simulate the sequencing of these samples with coverage of 2.5X by as it follows.

# let us simulate a 2.5x sequencing of the four sample
seq_results <- simulate_seq(phylo_forest, coverage = 2.5)

# let us load the dplyr library to filter the `simulate_seq` output
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

seq_results %>% head
#>   chromosome  chr_pos ref alt causes  classes S_1_1.occurrences S_1_1.coverage
#> 1         22 10510210   N   C      A   driver                 1              4
#> 2         22 16051493   G   A   <NA> germinal                 1              1
#> 3         22 16052080   G   A   <NA> germinal                 1              1
#> 4         22 16053659   A   C   <NA> germinal                 3              3
#> 5         22 16053863   G   A   <NA> germinal                 1              1
#> 6         22 16054740   A   G   <NA> germinal                 3              3
#>   S_1_1.VAF S_1_2.occurrences S_1_2.coverage S_1_2.VAF S_2_1.occurrences
#> 1      0.25                 2              2 1.0000000                 1
#> 2      1.00                 2              6 0.3333333                 3
#> 3      1.00                 3              3 1.0000000                 3
#> 4      1.00                 2              2 1.0000000                 4
#> 5      1.00                 0              2 0.0000000                 2
#> 6      1.00                 1              1 1.0000000                 3
#>   S_2_1.coverage S_2_1.VAF S_2_2.occurrences S_2_2.coverage S_2_2.VAF
#> 1              3 0.3333333                 1              2       0.5
#> 2              6 0.5000000                 2              4       0.5
#> 3              4 0.7500000                 3              5       0.6
#> 4              4 1.0000000                 3              3       1.0
#> 5              5 0.4000000                 0              1       0.0
#> 6              3 1.0000000                 6              6       1.0

The function simulate_seq returns a data frame whose rows represent the mutations observed in the simulated reads (currently, only SNVs are supported).

The number of columns in the data frame depends on the number of samples in the phygenetic forest. The first 4 columns describe the mutation and report the chromosome and the position in the chromosome of the mutation (columns “chromosome” and “chr_pos”, respectively), the genetic context in which the mutation occurs (column “context”), and the new base (column “alt_base”). Then, there are 3 columns for each of the samples: they contain the number of simulated reads affected by the mutation, the sequencing coverage of the mutation locus, and the ratio between these two last columns (columns “<sample name> occurrences”, “<sample name> coverage”, and “<sample name> VAF”, respectively).

Sample Purity and Normal Cell Sequencing

The sample purity represents the concentration of tumor cells in a sample. More formally, it is the ratio between the number of tumor cells in the sample and that of all the sample cells, being either tumor or normal cells.

rRACES can simulate different sample purity in sequencing simulations.

# simulate the sequencing of a sample in which 70% of the cells are
# tumor cells
seq_results <- simulate_seq(phylo_forest, coverage = 2.5, purity = 0.7)

The default value of the parameter purity is 1, i.e., simulate_seq assumes all the cells in the sample to be neoplastic by default.

The sequencing of a sample exclusively containing wild-type cells can be simulated by setting the parameter purity to 0.

Cell Partition by Epigenetic State (Epi-FACS)

The sequencing simulation supports cell partition by epigenetic state (epi-FACS) by using the simualate_seq parameter epi_FACS. At the beginning of the sequencing simulation process, each sample in the phylogenetic forest is splitted in two distinct samples: <sample name>_P, that contains all the cells in the original sample having epigenetic state +, and <sample name>_N, that consists in the cells having epigenetic state -. The results of the simulation reports the data for the splitted samples.

seq_results <- simulate_seq(phylo_forest, coverage = 2.5, epi_FACS = TRUE)

seq_results %>% head
#>   chromosome  chr_pos ref alt causes  classes S_1_1_N.occurrences
#> 1         22 10510210   N   C      A   driver                   2
#> 2         22 16051493   G   A   <NA> germinal                   1
#> 3         22 16052080   G   A   <NA> germinal                   0
#> 4         22 16053659   A   C   <NA> germinal                   3
#> 5         22 16053863   G   A   <NA> germinal                   0
#> 6         22 16054740   A   G   <NA> germinal                   4
#>   S_1_1_N.coverage S_1_1_N.VAF S_1_1_P.occurrences S_1_1_P.coverage S_1_1_P.VAF
#> 1                2           1                   1                1         1.0
#> 2                1           1                   3                6         0.5
#> 3                1           0                   1                1         1.0
#> 4                3           1                   2                2         1.0
#> 5                0         NaN                   0                2         0.0
#> 6                4           1                   2                2         1.0
#>   S_1_2_N.occurrences S_1_2_N.coverage S_1_2_N.VAF S_1_2_P.occurrences
#> 1                   1                3   0.3333333                   0
#> 2                   1                2   0.5000000                   1
#> 3                   2                2   1.0000000                   3
#> 4                   3                3   1.0000000                   2
#> 5                   3                6   0.5000000                   0
#> 6                   1                1   1.0000000                   4
#>   S_1_2_P.coverage S_1_2_P.VAF S_2_1_N.occurrences S_2_1_N.coverage S_2_1_N.VAF
#> 1                0         NaN                   1                1         1.0
#> 2                3   0.3333333                   2                5         0.4
#> 3                5   0.6000000                   2                2         1.0
#> 4                2   1.0000000                   2                2         1.0
#> 5                3   0.0000000                   0                2         0.0
#> 6                4   1.0000000                   8                8         1.0
#>   S_2_1_P.occurrences S_2_1_P.coverage S_2_1_P.VAF S_2_2_N.occurrences
#> 1                   2                4         0.5                   0
#> 2                   0                1         0.0                   2
#> 3                   0                0         NaN                   0
#> 4                   1                1         1.0                   2
#> 5                   0                0         NaN                   3
#> 6                   3                3         1.0                   2
#>   S_2_2_N.coverage S_2_2_N.VAF S_2_2_P.occurrences S_2_2_P.coverage S_2_2_P.VAF
#> 1                2           0                   1                1         1.0
#> 2                2           1                   0                2         0.0
#> 3                0         NaN                   1                1         1.0
#> 4                2           1                   3                3         1.0
#> 5                3           1                   1                2         0.5
#> 6                2           1                   3                3         1.0

Saving the Simulated Reads

rRACES/RACE can also save the simulated reads in the SAM format (see (Li et al. 2009)). By setting the optional parameter write_SAM to TRUE, the function simulate_seq creates the directory rRACES_SAM and saves the SAM files in it. Each file is named after one the reference genome chromosomes and it contains the reads simulated for it.

seq_results <- simulate_seq(phylo_forest, coverage = 2.5, write_SAM = TRUE)

SAM_files <- list.files("rRACES_SAM/")

ex_file <- paste("rRACES_SAM/", SAM_files[1], sep="")
for (line in readLines(ex_file, n = 10)) {
    cat(paste(line,"\n"))
}
#> @HD  VN:1.6  SO:unknown 
#> @SQ  SN:22   LN:51304566 AN:chromosome22,chr22,chromosome_22,chr_22 
#> @RG  ID:S_1_1 
#> @RG  ID:S_1_2 
#> @RG  ID:S_2_1 
#> @RG  ID:S_2_2 
#> r00000000000 0   22  37812620    33  150M    *   0   0   GAAGTGGGAGGGAAGGGCTGGGTGGAGGCACTGGGAGGAAGCAAGCGCTGGTGCAGCAGGGTCTCTGGTCTGTCCACAGGGGCAGGCAGGATAAGTGCAGACCCGCCCACTGTGCCTCACTCCCCAGCCCTCCACCACCAAGAACCCCCA  *   RG:Z:S_1_1 
#> r00000000001 16  22  50800045    33  150M    *   0   0   CTTGCCTTCAGCTATTTTTCCTTCAACAGTCTCAGCCCAGAGTATGCCCTGCTTGTCTTCCTTTGACCCAGGACCCAGAGTATGCCCTGCTCGTCTGCCTTTGACTCTTTGTTCTGGTACTTGTTTTCCCAGGATTATATTATTGACAAC  *   RG:Z:S_1_1 
#> r00000000002 16  22  25315049    33  150M    *   0   0   TCTGTCACCCAGGCTGGAGTGCAGTGGTGCAATCTCGGCTTACTGCAGCCTCCACTTCCTGGGTTCAAGCAATTCTCTGCCTCAGCCTCTTGAGTAGCTGGGATTACAGGCACCTGCCACCATGCCTGACTAATTTTTTTTGTATTTTTA  *   RG:Z:S_1_1 
#> r00000000003 16  22  17642772    33  150M    *   0   0   AAAAGAAAAAAAAAAAACCTGGAGTCTAATTCTAATTCCCCTCCCATTGAGTGTGGGCTGGACTTCACTGACTTTTTAATAAATAACATGGGACAGAAGTGAGTGTAGTTGATTTCCAAGGCTAGGTCATAAAAGATACTGTGACTTCCA  *   RG:Z:S_1_1

Each SAM file contains the reads produced by simulating the sequencing of all the samples. The command line tools samtools can be used to split the reads by sample (see here).

foo@bar % samtools split  -f "%*_%\!.sam" rRACES_SAM/chr_22.sam
foo@bar % ls chr_22_*
chr_22_S_1_1.sam        chr_22_S_1_2.sam        chr_22_S_2_1.sam        chr_22_S_2_2.sam

The resulting files are named after the phylogenetic forest samples and each of them contains the reads of only one sample.

Please, refer to the samtools split manual for more details.

Li, Heng, Bob Handsaker, Alec Wysoker, Tim Fennell, Jue Ruan, Nils Homer, Gabor Marth, Goncalo Abecasis, Richard Durbin, and 1000 Genome Project Data Processing Subgroup. 2009. “The Sequence Alignment/Map format and SAMtools.” Bioinformatics 25 (16): 2078–79. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btp352.
